problem: {name1}, {name2}, and {name3} are trying to collect {collection_item_plural}. Together they have collected {total_items} {collection_item_plural}. {name1} has collected {a} more than {name2}, and {name2} has collected {b} less than {c} times as many as {name3} has collected. How many {collection_item_plural} has {name2} collected?

{name} wants to enjoy some {food_item}. According to the nutritional info, a bag of {food_item} has {calories_per_serving} calories per serving. If a {bag_weight}g bag has {servings_per_bag} servings, how many grams can {name} eat if {name}'s daily calorie target is {daily_calorie_target} calories and {name} has already consumed {calories_consumed} calories?
solution:
If {name}'s total calorie target is {daily_calorie_target} calories and {name} has consumed {calories_consumed} calories, then {name} has {daily_calorie_target} - {calories_consumed} = <<{daily_calorie_target}-{calories_consumed}={remaining_calories}>>{remaining_calories} calories left to eat.
Each serving of {food_item} has {calories_per_serving} calories, so {name} can eat {remaining_calories} / {calories_per_serving} = <<{remaining_calories}/{calories_per_serving}={servings_can_eat}>>{servings_can_eat} servings.
A {bag_weight}g bag of {food_item} has {servings_per_bag} servings, so each serving is {bag_weight}g / {servings_per_bag} = <<{bag_weight}/{servings_per_bag}={serving_size}>>{serving_size} grams.
Therefore, {name} can eat {serving_size}g * {servings_can_eat} = <<{serving_size}*{servings_can_eat}={grams_can_eat}>>{grams_can_eat} grams.
#### {grams_can_eat}

problem: {buyer_name} buys {number_per_person} {item_plural} for each of {number_of_people} {people_relation}. They cost ${item_cost} each. How much did {buyer_name} pay?

{name} decides to {activity_description}. {he_she} does {first_day_pushups} pushups, {first_day_squats} squats, and {first_day_dumbbell_presses} dumbbell presses on the first day. On the second day, {he_she} does {pushup_change} more pushups than on the first day, {squat_change} fewer squats, and {dumbbell_press_multiplier} times the number of dumbbell presses. What's the total count of the activities {he_she} has done in the two days?

name: Darren
Alex
Sam
Jordan
Taylor
Morgan
Casey
Jamie
Riley
Chris
activity_description: get in shape for the summer

solution:
The total count of activities for the first day is {first_day_pushups} + {first_day_squats} + {first_day_dumbbell_presses} = <<{first_day_pushups}+{first_day_squats}+{first_day_dumbbell_presses}={first_day_total}>>{first_day_total}.

On the second day, {he_she} does {first_day_pushups} + {pushup_change} = <<{first_day_pushups}+{pushup_change}={second_day_pushups}>>{second_day_pushups} pushups.

{he_she} also does {first_day_squats} - {squat_change} = <<{first_day_squats}-{squat_change}={second_day_squats}>>{second_day_squats} squats.

For the dumbbell presses, {he_she} multiplies the number from the first day by {dumbbell_press_multiplier}, which becomes {dumbbell_press_multiplier} * {first_day_dumbbell_presses} = <<{dumbbell_press_multiplier}*{first_day_dumbbell_presses}={second_day_dumbbell_presses}>>{second_day_dumbbell_presses}.

The total count for the three activities on the second day is {second_day_pushups} + {second_day_squats} + {second_day_dumbbell_presses} = <<{second_day_pushups}+{second_day_squats}+{second_day_dumbbell_presses}={second_day_total}>>{second_day_total}.

For the two days, {he_she} has a total count for all three activities of {first_day_total} + {second_day_total} = <<{first_day_total}+{second_day_total}={total_activities}>>{total_activities}.
#### {total_activities}

problem: {store_name} sells {item_category}. One {item1_name} is sold at ${item1_price} each, a {item2_name} at ${item2_price} each, a {item3_name} at ${item3_price} each, and a {item4_name} at ${item4_price} each. {customer_name} is a {customer_description}, and {he_she} wants to buy {item1_quantity} {item1_name_plural}, {item2_quantity} {item2_name_plural}, {item3_quantity} {item3_name_plural}, and {item4_quantity} {item4_name_plural}. The shop gives a {discount_percentage}% discount on all the purchased items. How much does {customer_name} have to spend on all the items {he_she} wants to buy?
solution:
{item1_quantity} {item1_name_plural} cost {item1_quantity} x ${item1_price} = $<<{item1_quantity}*{item1_price}={item1_total}>>{item1_total}.
{item2_quantity} {item2_name_plural} cost {item2_quantity} x ${item2_price} = $<<{item2_quantity}*{item2_price}={item2_total}>>{item2_total}.
{item3_quantity} {item3_name_plural} cost {item3_quantity} x ${item3_price} = $<<{item3_quantity}*{item3_price}={item3_total}>>{item3_total}.
{item4_quantity} {item4_name_plural} cost {item4_quantity} x ${item4_price} = $<<{item4_quantity}*{item4_price}={item4_total}>>{item4_total}.
The total cost is ${item1_total} + ${item2_total} + ${item3_total} + ${item4_total} = $<<{item1_total}+{item2_total}+{item3_total}+{item4_total}={total_cost_before_discount}>>{total_cost_before_discount}.
The total discount is {discount_percentage}% of ${total_cost_before_discount} = $<<{discount_percentage}*{total_cost_before_discount}/100={total_discount}>>{total_discount}.
Therefore, {customer_name} has to spend ${total_cost_before_discount} - ${total_discount} = $<<{total_cost_before_discount}-{total_discount}={total_cost_after_discount}>>{total_cost_after_discount} on all the items {he_she} wants to buy.
#### {total_cost_after_discount}

problem: On Monday, {name1} ate {multiplier_monday} times as many {food_item_plural} as {name2}. On Tuesday, {name1} ate {multiplier_tuesday} times as many {food_item_plural} as {name2}. {name2} ate {name2_monday} {food_item_plural} on Monday and {name2_tuesday} the next day. If 1 {food_item_singular} has {calories_per_item} calories, how many more calories did {name1} consume than {name2}?
solution:
{name1}'s Monday {food_item_singular} intake is {multiplier_monday} * {name2_monday} = <<{multiplier_monday}*{name2_monday}={name1_monday}>>{name1_monday}.
{name1}'s Tuesday {food_item_singular} intake is {multiplier_tuesday} * {name2_tuesday} = <<{multiplier_tuesday}*{name2_tuesday}={name1_tuesday}>>{name1_tuesday}.
Total {food_item_plural} {name1} consumed is {name1_monday} + {name1_tuesday} = <<{name1_monday}+{name1_tuesday}={name1_total}>>{name1_total}.
{name2} ate a total of {name2_monday} + {name2_tuesday} = <<{name2_monday}+{name2_tuesday}={name2_total}>>{name2_total} {food_item_plural}.
{name1} ate {name1_total} - {name2_total} = <<{name1_total}-{name2_total}={difference_in_items}>>{difference_in_items} more {food_item_plural}.
{name1} consumed {difference_in_items} * {calories_per_item} = <<{difference_in_items}*{calories_per_item}={total_calories_difference}>>{total_calories_difference} more calories.
#### {total_calories_difference}

problem: {buyer_name} went to buy {item_plural} from the store and spent ${total_spent} on the {item_plural}. If each {item_singular} was ${item_price} and {he_she} gave an equal number of {item_plural} to {his_her} {number_of_kids} {kids}, how many {item_plural} did each child get?

{name} is traveling on the interstate at an average speed of {speed} km/hr (taking into account all the necessary stops for gas, relaxation, etc.). If {he_she} goes on like this for {days} days, and the distance between {place1} and {place2} is {total_distance} km, what percentage of this distance has {he_she} covered?
solution:
There are 24 hours in each day, so {name} has been traveling for a total of {days} * 24 = <<{days}*24={total_hours}>>{total_hours} hours.
At a rate of {speed} km/hr, {he_she} has covered {speed} * {total_hours} = <<{speed}*{total_hours}={distance_covered}>>{distance_covered} km.
{distance_covered} km as a percentage of {total_distance} km is ({distance_covered}/{total_distance})*100% = <<({distance_covered}/{total_distance})*100={percentage_covered}>>{percentage_covered}%
#### {percentage_covered}
